{{Infobox person | name = Serge Klarsfeld | pronunciation = | image = Serge Klarsfeld par Claude Truong-Ngoc septembre 2015.jpg | caption = Serge Klarsfeld (as in 2015) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1935|9|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]] | nationality = [[French people|French]] | spouse = [[Beate Klarsfeld]] (1963-present); 2 children | known_for = French activist and [[Nazi hunter]] | website = {{URL|http://www.klarsfeldfoundation.org/}} }}
'''Serge Klarsfeld''' (born 17 September 1935) is a Romanian-born French activist and [[Nazi hunter]] known for documenting the [[Holocaust]] in order to establish the record and to enable the prosecution of war criminals. Since the 1960s, he has made notable efforts to commemorate the Jewish victims of [[German military administration in occupied France during World War II|German-occupied France]] and has been a supporter of [[Israel]].
==Life== He helped found and has led the [[Sons and Daughters of Jewish Deportees from France]] (''Association des fils et filles des déportés juifs de France)'' or FFDJF. It is one of the groups that has documented cases and located former German and French officials for prosecution such as [[Klaus Barbie]], [[René Bousquet]], [[Jean Leguay]], [[Maurice Papon]] and [[Paul Touvier]], who have been implicated in the deaths of hundreds of thousands of French and foreign Jews during the Second World War. The Klarsfelds were among organised groups who filed cases decades after the war, sometimes as late as the 1990s, against such officials for their crimes against humanity.
In the years before 1989 and the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|break-up of the Soviet Union]], the Klarsfelds (Serge Klarsfeld and his wife [[Beate Klarsfeld|Beate]]) frequently protested against the [[Eastern Bloc]]'s support for the [[PLO]] and [[Antisemitism in the Soviet Union|anti-Zionism]].
Recognition for their work has included [[France]]'s [[Légion d'honneur|Legion of Honour]] in 1984.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.klarsfeldfoundation.org/chrono/timeline2.htm |title=Klarsfeldfoundation.org |publisher=Klarsfeldfoundation.org |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308190646/http://www.klarsfeldfoundation.org/chrono/timeline2.htm |archivedate=2012-03-08 |df= }}</ref> In 1986, their story was adapted as an American television film starring [[Tom Conti]], [[Farrah Fawcett]] and [[Geraldine Page]]. In 2008, a French television movie was made about them.
On 1 January 2014, the Klarsfelds' [[Legion of Honour]] ranks were upgraded: Serge became ''Grand officier''.<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2014/01/02/1786361-legion-d-honneur-michele-morgan-alain-decaux-serge-klarsfeld.html |title=La légion d'honneur pour Michèle Morgan, Alain Decaux, Serge Klarsfeld |website=La Dépêche |date=January 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>Jennifer Schuessler. Arts, Briefly. ''[[The New York Times]]'', Thursday, 2 January 2014, p. C2, under "[[Danielle Steel]] Awarded French Legion of Honor": "Among the other honorees were the Nazi hunter Serge Klarsfeld."</ref>
On 26 October 2015, the UNESCO designate the Klarsfelds as "Honourary Ambassadors and Special Envoys for Education about the Holocaust and the Prevention of Genocide".<ref name="unesco-2015">{{cite web |title=UNESCO Honours Beate and Serge Klarsfeld, for their work to preserve the history and teaching of the Holocaust |url=http://en.unesco.org/news/unesco-honours-beate-and-serge-klarsfeld-their-work-preserve-history-and-teaching-holocaust |website=UNESCO |date=October 26, 2015}}</ref>
== Early years == Serge Klarsfeld was born in [[Bucharest]] into a family of Romanian Jews. They migrated to France before the Second World War began. In 1943, his father was arrested by the [[Schutzstaffel|SS]] in [[Nice]] during a roundup ordered by [[Alois Brunner]]. Deported to the [[Auschwitz concentration camp]], Klarsfeld's father died there. Young Serge was cared for in a home for Jewish children operated by the OSE ([[Œuvre de secours aux enfants]])<ref>[http://www.ose-france.org/ ose-france.org]</ref>{{failed verification|date=January 2016}} organization; his mother and sister also survived the war in [[Vichy France]], helped by the underground [[French Resistance]] beginning in late 1943.<ref name="unesco-2015" />
==Marriage and family== Serge married [[Beate Klarsfeld|Beate Künzel]] in 1963 and settled in Paris. Their son, {{Interlanguage link multi|Arno Klarsfeld|fr}} (born 1965), became a [[human rights]] attorney and worked for [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] while he was minister of the interior.
== Activism ==
===Early activism=== In 2012 the archivist of the [[Stasi]] revealed that [[Beate Klarsfeld]]'s attack on German Chancellor [[Kurt Georg Kiesinger]] by publicly slapping him on 7 November 1968<ref name="SPON-948002">{{cite web|title=Klarsfeld-Skandal: Klatsche für den Kanzler|trans-title=|periodical=[[Spiegel Online]]|publisher=|url=http://www.spiegel.de/einestages/40-jahre-klarsfeld-skandal-a-948002.html|accessdate=2016-12-31|last=Axel Frohn|date=2008-11-07|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}}</ref> was carried out in agreement with and the support of the government of [[East Germany]], which was conducting a campaign against West German politicians (see [[Braunbuch]]).<ref name="morgenpost1">{{cite web |language=de |url=http://www.morgenpost.de/politik/inland/article1919046/Klarsfelds-Ohrfeige-war-mit-DDR-abgesprochen.html |author=<!--staff authors, no byline--> |title=Bundespräsidentschafts-Kandidatin - Klarsfelds Ohrfeige war mit DDR abgesprochen |trans-title=Klarsfeld Slap Prearranged with GDR |website=Berliner Morgenpost |location=Berlin |publisher=Morgenpost.de |date=2012-03-03 |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web |language=de |url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/bundespraesidentenwahl-klarsfeld-hatte-aktionen-gegen-kiesinger-mit-ddr-besprochen-11670940.html |author=<!--staff authors, no byline--> |title=Bundespräsidentenwahl: Klarsfeld hatte Aktionen gegen Kiesinger mit DDR besprochen |trans-title=Klarsfled Arranged Action Against Kiesinger with GDR |publisher=FAZ |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> Beate Klarsfeld was paid 2,000 DM by the Stasi for her actions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bild.de/politik/inland/beate-klarsfeld/sed-geld-fuer-klarsfeld-23049434.bild.html |title=Präsidentschaftskandidatin der Linken: SED-Geld für Klarsfeld? |trans-title=Presidential Candidate of the Left: SED-Cash for Klarsfeld? |language=de |publisher=Bild.de |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |language=de |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,819994,00.html |title=Angeblicher SED-Dank: Klarsfeld soll 2000 Mark für Kiesinger-Ohrfeige erhalten haben |website=SPIEGEL ONLINE |trans-title=Alleged SED Reward: 2000 Marks to Klarsfeld for Kiesinger Slap |publisher=Spiegel.de |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> Both Serge and Beate Klarsfeld were revealed to have been regular [[Stasi]] contacts.<ref name="tagesspiegel1">{{cite web |language=de |author=Von Matthias Meisner |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/praesidenschaftskandidatin-der-linkspartei-ddr-buergerrechtler-rathenow-hinterfragt-klarsfelds-stasikontakte/6268698.html |title=Präsidenschaftskandidatin der Linkspartei: DDR-Bürgerrechtler Rathenow hinterfragt Klarsfelds Stasikontakte |website=Tagesspiegel |trans-title=Presidential Candidate of the Left party: DDR Human Rights Campaigner Rathenow Scrutinizes Klarsfelds Contacts With Stasi |publisher=Tagesspiegel.de |date=2012-02-29 |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> According to the State Commissioner for the Stasi Archives of [[Saxony]], they cooperated with the Stasi in the 1960s in [[blackmail]]ing West German politicians for Second World War activities.<ref>{{cite web |language=de |url=http://www.stern.de/news2/aktuell/ex-ddr-buergerrechtler-wirft-klarsfeld-stasi-kontakte-vor-1793414.html |title=Ex-DDR-Bürgerrechtler wirft Klarsfeld Stasi-Kontakte vor |trans-title=Ex GDR Human Rights Campaigner Accuses Klarsfeld as Stasi Contact |publisher=Stern.De |date=2012-02-06 |accessdate=2012-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304072557/http://www.stern.de/news2/aktuell/ex-ddr-buergerrechtler-wirft-klarsfeld-stasi-kontakte-vor-1793414.html |archivedate=2012-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
In 1974, Serge and [[Beate Klarsfeld]] were both convicted in West Germany on [[felony]] charges of attempted [[kidnapping]] of [[Kurt Lischka]], a former [[Gestapo]] chief, in [[Cologne]] in order to transport him to France for prosecution. After conviction of felony charges, they were each sentenced to two months in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.wdr.de/themen/politik/lischka100.html |title=Versuchte Entführung von Kurt Lischka - Politik - WDR.de |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> (His prosecution in Germany was prevented by legal technicalities resulting from a prior conviction). Following international protests, the sentence was suspended. Activism by the Klarsfelds and by descendants of Lischka's victims eventually resulted in changes to the laws. In 1980, Lischka was convicted of a felony in West Germany and sentenced to prison.
===Attack on the Klarsfelds=== The Klarsfelds' activities and methods generated controversy. On 9 July 1979, the Klarsfelds were the targets of car bombing at their home in [[France]]. No one was in the car when the bomb detonated, and no one was injured in the vicinity of the blast. Individuals purporting to represent the Nazi [[ODESSA]] claimed responsibility for the attack.
===Later activism=== They are notable in the postwar decades for having been involved in hunting and finding German Nazis and French Vichy officials responsible for the worst abuses of the Holocaust, in order to prosecute them for alleged war crimes. Several officials were indicted due in part to the work of the Klarsfelds; they included the following, with the years of their convictions or deaths in parentheses: *[[Klaus Barbie]] (1987) *[[René Bousquet]] (1993) *[[Jean Leguay]] (1989) *[[Maurice Papon]] (1998) *[[Paul Touvier]] (1994)
In the 1970s the Klarsfelds considered kidnapping [[Klaus Barbie|Barbie]] in much the same way the [[Mossad]] did [[Eichmann]] but the plan fell through. They decided instead to bring international pressure to force his extradition.
By 1995, only four senior French [[Vichy France|Vichy]] officials had been indicted for war crimes, and by that year, only [[Paul Touvier]] had stood trial.<ref name="Dejevsky">[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/killers-tale-stirs-ghosts-of-vichy-1580759.html MARY DEJEVSKY, "Killer's tale stirs ghosts of Vichy"], ''The Independent'' (UK), 7 November 1995, 28 May 2012</ref> Like Touvier, the former Vichy official [[Maurice Papon]] was convicted of war crimes in 1998.
The Klarsfelds continued to publicize the wartime activities of prominent politicians in Germany and Austria. In 1986 the Klarsfelds campaigned against former [[United Nations Secretary-General]] [[Kurt Waldheim]], who was elected [[President of Austria]] amid allegations that he had covered up his wartime activities as an officer in the [[Wehrmacht]].
In 1996, during the warfare in the [[former Yugoslavia]], the Klarsfelds joined the outcry against [[Radovan Karadžić]] and [[Ratko Mladić]] for alleged [[war crimes]] and [[genocide]] of [[Bosnians|Bosnian]] [[Muslims]].
In December 2009, Serge Klarsfeld defied an existing consensus within the Jewish community by saying that the [[beatification]] of Pope [[Pius XII]] was an internal matter of the Church. He said that Jews should not get too involved in the process.<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-societe/2009-12-24/interview-serge-klarsfeld-il-n-y-a-aucune-raison-pour-que-pie-xii-ne/920/0/407982 |title=Serge Klarsfeld : "Il n'y a aucune raison pour que Pie XII ne devienne pas saint" |trans-title=Serge Klarsfeld: "There is no reason why Pius XII shouldn't become a saint" |website= Le Point| publisher=Lepoint.fr |date= 24 December 2009|accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> Many Jews were protesting the beatification, as they said that Pius XII had contributed to the persecution of Jews throughout Europe, and had not brought the power of the church against the Nazis for their mistreatment of Jews and other persecuted peoples.
===Activism in France=== In France in 1979 the Klarsfelds created ''[[Sons and daughters of Jewish Deportees from France|l'Association des fils et filles des déportés juifs de France]]'' (Association of the sons and daughters of Jews deported from France) or FFDJF. It defends the cause of the descendants of deportees, to have the events recognised and to prosecute people responsible. In 1981, the association commissioned a memorial in Israel to the deported French Jews; it bears the name, date and place of birth of 80,000 French victims of the Nazi extermination. About 80,000 trees were planted to shape a forest of remembrance. Serge Klarsfeld is also Vice-President of the [[Fondation pour la Mémoire de la Shoah]].
In 1989 FFDJF was one of the groups to file a case against [[René Bousquet]], head of the French Police in the Vichy government, for crimes against humanity. He was indicted by the French government in 1991, but killed in 1993 shortly before his trial was to begin.
The Klarsfelds' work on behalf of the descendants of Jewish deportees was formally recognised by President [[Jacques Chirac]] in a 1995 speech.<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.elysee.fr/elysee/francais/interventions/discours_et_declaration/1995/juillet/allocution_de_m_jacques_chirac_president_de_la_republique_prononcee_lors_des_ceremonies_commemorant_la_grande_rafle_des_16_et_17_juillet_1942-paris.2503.html |title=(--)}} {{dead link|date=February 2013}}</ref> He acknowledged the nation's responsibility for the fate of Jews in its territory during the Second World War. The government passed a law on 13 July 2000 to establish compensation for orphans whose parents were victims of anti-Semitic persecution.
On 7 July 2010, Serge Klarsfeld was awarded the title of [[Legion of Honour|commandeur de la Légion d'honneur]] by Prime Minister [[François Fillon]] at [[Hôtel Matignon]], the official residence of France's Prime Minister.<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.fondationshoah.info/FMS/IMG/pdf/Discours_Fillon_-_LH_S_Klarsfeld.pdf |title=Discours de M. François Fillon, Premier ministre. Remise des insignes de commandeur de la Légion d'honneur à M. Serge Klarsfeld. Hôtel Matignon |trans-title=Speech of Prime Minister François Fillon. Decoration of Serge Klarsfeld with the Insignia of the Commander of the Legion of Honor at Hotel Matignon. |format=PDF |date=July 7, 2010 |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.fondationshoah.info/FMS/IMG/pdf/Discours_SK_Matignon_07_07_10.pdf |title=Discours de M. Serge Klarsfeld. Remise des insignes de commandeur de la Légion d'honneur. Hôtel Matignon |trans-title=Speech of Serge Klarsfled. Decoration of Serge Klarsfeld with the Insignia of the Commander of the Legion of Honor at Hotel Matignon. |date=July 7, 2010 |format=PDF |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref>
In January 2012, the Klarsfelds, along with prominent French-Armenian singer [[Charles Aznavour]], director [[Robert Guédiguian]], and philosophers [[Bernard-Henri Lévy]] and [[Michel Onfray]], signed an appeal to the French Parliament to ratify a bill to establish penalties for people who deny the [[Armenian Genocide]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.am/eng/news/88045.html |title=Aznavour, philosophers, Turkish writer call French Senate to ratify bill penalizing Armenian Genocide | Armenia News |publisher=NEWS.am |date=2009-06-13 |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.armenews.com/article.php3?id_article=75888 |title=Nouvelles d'Arménie en Ligne |trans-title=Armenia News Online |publisher=Armenews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107011338/http://www.armenews.com/article.php3?id_article=75888 |archive-date=2016-01-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
In July 2018, the Klarsfelds were profiled at length on CNN, which noted their swing away from Nazi hunting to a more-general push for social justice in opposition to the modern right.<ref name="20180704CNN">{{cite news |last1=Andelman |first1=David |title=From Nazi hunters to warriors against today's fascism |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/04/opinions/klarsfelds-europe-resurgent-extreme-right/index.html |accessdate=5 July 2018 |work=[[CNN]] |date=4 July 2018}}</ref> Today, they fight for human life, freedom, and social protection.<ref name="20180704CNN" />
==Cooperation with the Stasi== Since the reunification of Germany and the opening of Stasi files, in 2012 [[Lutz Rathenow]], the State Commissioner for the Stasi Archives of [[Saxony]], has stated that Beate Klarsfeld cooperated with the [[Stasi]] of [[East Germany]] in the 1960s. They gave her material containing incriminating information about the wartime activities of West German politicians.<ref>[http://www.stern.de/news2/aktuell/ex-ddr-buergerrechtler-wirft-klarsfeld-stasi-kontakte-vor-1793414.html Ex-DDR-Bürgerrechtler wirft Klarsfeld Stasi-Kontakte vor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304072557/http://www.stern.de/news2/aktuell/ex-ddr-buergerrechtler-wirft-klarsfeld-stasi-kontakte-vor-1793414.html |date=2012-03-04 }}, Stern, 29 February 2012</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article13904656/Nazi-Jaegerin-Klarsfeld-ist-mehr-Mythos-als-Wahrheit.html |title=Klaus Barbie: Nazi-Jägerin Klarsfeld ist mehr Mythos als Wahrheit - Nachrichten Politik - Deutschland - WELT ONLINE |language=de |publisher=Welt.de |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> The cooperation of both Beate and Serge Klarsfeld with the Stasi and their status as contacts was also documented in a new book by former Stasi officers, Günter Bohnsack and Herbert Brehmer.<ref name="tagesspiegel1"/>
==Later years in Germany== In May 2015, Beate Klarsfeld and her husband Serge received the German [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany|Federal Cross of Merit]], in recognition of their efforts to bring Nazi war criminals to justice.
== Honours == * '''2014''':Grand officer of the [[Legion of Honour]] * '''2015''' : Officer of the [[Order of Saint-Charles]].<ref>http://www.legimonaco.mc/Dataweb/jourmon.nsf/56ae81d1d4180496c12568ce002f290a/e31dd7a86b8d13c9c1257f010055f9a7/$FILE/JO8252%20OS%205.556.pdf</ref>
==Representation in other media== *The Klarsfelds' activities related to finding Nazi war criminals were the subject of ''[[Nazi Hunter: The Beate Klarsfeld Story]]'' (1986), an American made-for-TV film. *The documentary ''La traque des nazis,'' (2007) studied [[Simon Wiesenthal]]'s and the Klarsfelds' activities.<ref>[http://www.vodeo.tv/lire/5-31-4100-la-traque-des-nazis.html Vodeo.tv] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218152045/http://www.vodeo.tv/lire/5-31-4100-la-traque-des-nazis.html |date=February 18, 2008 }}</ref> *The 2008 drama ''La traque'' was a French made-for-TV film, written by Alexandra Deman and Laurent Jaoui and directed by Laurent Jaoui, based on the Klarsfelds. *The 2001 Documentary "[[Marlene Dietrich]]: Her Own Song" a Turner Classic Movies Production about Dietrich mentioning her support of Klarsfeld's anti-Nazi activities.

{{Infobox baseball biography | name = Steve Olin | image = Steve Olin.JPG | caption = Steve Olin in uniform | position = [[Pitcher]] | birth_date = October 4, 1965 | birth_place = [[Portland, Oregon]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1993|3|22|1965|10|4}} | death_place = Little Lake Nellie, [[Clermont, Florida]] | bats = Right | throws = Right |debutleague = MLB | debutdate = July 29 | debutyear = 1989 | debutteam = Cleveland Indians |finalleague = MLB | finaldate = October 4 | finalyear = 1992 | finalteam = Cleveland Indians |statleague = MLB | stat1label = [[Win–loss record (pitching)|Win–loss record]] | stat1value = 16–19 | stat2label = [[Earned run average]] | stat2value = 3.10 | stat3label = [[Strikeout]]s | stat3value = 173 | stat4label = [[Save (baseball)|Saves]] | stat4value = 48 | teams = * [[Cleveland Indians]] ({{By|1989}}–{{By|1992}}) }} '''Steven Robert Olin''' (October 4, 1965 – March 22, 1993) was an American right-handed [[pitcher]] in [[Major League Baseball]] who played for four seasons in the [[American League]] with the [[Cleveland Indians]]. Olin was a right-handed [[submarine (baseball)|submarining]] [[relief pitcher]] for the [[Cleveland Indians]] from [[1988 in baseball|1988]] to [[1992 in baseball|1992]]. Olin died in a 1993 boating accident while still an active MLB player.
==Early life== Steve Olin was born on October 4, 1965 in [[Portland, Oregon]], and grew up in nearby [[Beaverton, Oregon|Beaverton]].<ref name=obit>{{cite news |first=Murray |last=Chass |authorlink=Murray Chass |title=Boat Accident Kills Indians' Top Reliever |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/03/23/sports/baseball-boat-accident-kills-indians-top-reliever.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 23, 1993 |accessdate=March 2, 2012}}</ref> He graduated from [[Beaverton High School]] in 1984, and was recruited by baseball coach Jack Dunn to attend [[Portland State University]].<ref name=akron>{{cite news |title=Portland Coach Watched Olin From Little League Pitcher's Death a Deep Loss to Friend Who Guided Him Through College Career |newspaper=[[Akron Beacon Journal]] |page=A10 (Sports) |date=March 24, 1993}}</ref>
==Career== In 195 career games, Olin pitched 273 [[innings pitched|innings]] and posted a [[win (baseball)|win–loss record]] of 16–19, with 48 [[save (baseball)|saves]], 118 games finished, and a 3.10 [[earned run average]] (ERA). He earned his final win on September 9, 1992 against the Milwaukee Brewers. Noteworthy, as that was the game in which Robin Yount recorded his 3,000th career hit, though fellow pitcher [[José Mesa]] actually gave up the hit earlier in the game. Olin won the game in relief when Cleveland scored two runs in the top of the ninth.
==Death== Olin was killed in a boating accident during [[spring training]] of 1993 on Little Lake Nellie in [[Clermont, Florida]]. The boat he was in struck a pier, killing him and fellow reliever [[Tim Crews]] and seriously injuring [[Bob Ojeda]]. Crews, who was piloting the boat, was legally drunk at the time; Olin and Ojeda only had negligible traces of alcohol in their bodies.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/26/sports/baseball-ojeda-discusses-the-crash.html |title=Baseball; Ojeda Discusses The Crash |date=June 26, 1993 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> It was the first death of active major league players since [[Thurman Munson]] in 1979. In response to the accident that took Olin and Crews in 1993, the Indians wore a patch on the sleeves of their jerseys. It consisted of a baseball with their numbers on it. Olin's #31 is on the left, with an arrow above. Crews' #52 is on the right, with a star above it.
==Remembrance== [[The Beatles]] song "[[Yellow Submarine (song)|Yellow Submarine]]" has a unique meaning in Cleveland, since it was played before each of submariner Olin's appearances for the Indians in home games.
Another song remembered by Cleveland locals is "[[The Dance (song)|The Dance]]" by [[Garth Brooks]]. The song, a favorite of Olin, was played when the Indians clinched the 1995 American League Central Division. Before the game, then manager [[Mike Hargrove]] phoned the Indians scoreboard room requesting that it be played when the Indians clinched.
{{quote|"I thought it would mean a lot to anyone who was there (with the Indians at the time of the accident)", said Hargrove. "For those who weren't there it had no significance, but it was still a good song. It was a tribute to those guys, to their families. It was part of our promise to never forget them. We didn't tell anyone that we were going to do it. For those who knew, there wasn't a dry eye to be seen. I saw Charlie Nagy; tears were rolling down his face."<ref>{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Kurkjian |authorlink=Tim Kurkjian |title=In times of despair, Hargrove stands tall |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/columns/story?columnist=kurkjian_tim&id=1526751 |work=ESPN |date=March 21, 2003 |accessdate=March 2, 2012}}</ref>}}
==See also== *[[List of baseball players who died during their careers]] *[[List of Major League Baseball all-time saves leaders]]

{{hatnote|This article is about the modern Bulgarian people from [[Thrace]]; for the ancient people, see [[Thracians]]; for all other uses, see [[Thracian (disambiguation)|Thracian]] (disambiguation).}} [[Image:Bulgarian refugees from Bulgarkyoi 1913.jpg|thumb|Right|190px|Bulgarian refugees from [[Eastern Thrace]], expelled by the Ottomans, 1913.]] [[File:Thracian refugees.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Bulgarian refugees from [[Komotini]], expelled by the Greeks, 1924.]] {{Bulgarians}} '''Thracians'''<ref>The Thracian and His World. Proceedings of the eighth National Conference of Bulgarian Ethnologists, Haskovo 1995. Sofia, 1 Publication: ETHNOLOGIA BULGARICA. Yearbook of Bulgarian Ethnology and Folklore (2/2001), Stamenova, Jivka; Language: English Subject: Anthropology, Issue: 2/2001, Page Range: 141-143</ref> or '''Thracian Bulgarians'''<ref>Groups of Bulgarian population and ethnographic groups, Bulgarian Ethnology (March 1987), Simeonova, Gatya; Language: Bulgarian, Subject: Anthropology, Issue: 3/1987, Page Range: 55-63.</ref> ([[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]]: Тракийски българи or Тракийци) are a regional, [[ethnographic]] group of ethnic [[Bulgarians]], inhabiting or native to [[Thrace]]. Today, the larger part of this population is concentrated in [[Northern Thrace]], but much is spread across the whole of [[Bulgaria]] and the [[Bulgarian diaspora|diaspora]].
Until the beginning of the twentieth century the Thracian Bulgarians lived also in the whole of [[Thrace]], then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. After the persecutions during the [[Preobrazhenie Uprising]] and the [[ethnic cleansing]], caused to the Bulgarian population in [[Eastern Thrace]] after the [[Second Balkan War]], these people were expelled from the area. After [[World War I]], Bulgaria was required to cede Western Thrace to Greece. A whole population of Bulgarians in [[Western Thrace]] was expelled into Bulgaria-controlled Northern Thrace. This was followed by a further population exchange between Bulgaria and Greece (under the [[Treaty of Neuilly-sur-Seine]]), which radically changed the demographics of the region toward increased ethnic homogenization within the territories each respective country ultimately was awarded. At this period the [[Bulgarian Communist Party]] was compelled by [[Comintern]] to accept the formation of a new ''Thracian nation'' on the base of this people in order to include them in a new separate ''Thracian state'', as a part of a future [[Balkan Communist Federation]].<ref>V, Joseph. The Communist Party of Bulgaria; Origins and Development, 1883-1936. Columbia University Press. p. 126.</ref>
The last flow of Thracian refugees into Bulgaria was as the Bulgarian Army pulled out of the [[Serres]]-[[Drama]] region in late 1944.<ref>Migrattsionni protsesi v Bŭlgariiia sled Vtorata svetovna voina, Boika Vasileva, Univ. izd-vo "Sv. Kliment Okhridski", 1991, str. 138-146.</ref>
With the accession of Bulgaria into the European Union, Bulgarian authorities appear to revisit the issue as a precondition for [[Accession of Turkey to the European Union|Turkey's membership to the Union]].<ref>[http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=109626 Bulgaria: Bulgaria Backs Thrace Refugees in Claiming Compensations from Turkey - Sofia News Agency]</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Tsianina Redfeather | image = Tsianina Redfeather Blackstone in 1915 looking forward.jpg | alt = Tsianina Redfeather in 1915 | caption = Tsianina Redfeather in 1915 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1882|12|13}} | birth_place = [[Eufaula, Oklahoma]]/[[Muscogee Creek Nation]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1985|01|10|1882|12|13}} | death_place = [[San Diego, California]] | nationality = American | other_names = Tsianina Blackstone, Tsianina Grayson | occupation = opera singer and activist | notable_works = Libretto for [[Shanewis]] }} [[File:Tsianina Redfeather.jpg|thumb|Tsianina Redfeather in 1917-1918.]]
'''Tsianina Redfeather Blackstone''' (December 13, 1882 – January 10, 1985) was a Creek/Cherokee singer and performer born in [[Eufaula, Oklahoma]], then within the [[Muscogee Creek Nation]]. From 1908 she toured regularly with [[Charles Wakefield Cadman]], a composer and pianist who gave lectures about Native American music that were accompanied by his compositions and her singing. He composed classically based works associated with the [[Indianist movement]]. They toured in the United States and Europe.
She collaborated with him and [[Nelle Richmond Eberhart]] on the libretto of the opera ''[[Shanewis]]'' (or "The Robin Woman," 1918), which was based on her semi-autobiographical stories and contemporary issues for Native Americans. It premiered at the [[Metropolitan Opera]]. Redfeather sang the title role when the opera was on tour, making her debut when the work was performed in Denver in 1924, and also performing in it in Los Angeles in 1926.
After her performing career, she worked as an activist on Indian education, co-founding the [[American Indian Education Foundation]]. She also supported Native American archeology and ethnology, serving on the Board of Managers for the [[School of American Research]] founded in Santa Fe by [[Alice Cunningham Fletcher]].
== Early life == Tsianina Redfeather was born Florence ''Tsianina'' Evans at [[Eufaula, Oklahoma|Eufaula]], in Indian Territory (now [[Oklahoma]]), to [[Muscogee (Creek)|Creek]] and [[Cherokee]] parents.<ref name="muskogeeTimes">[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1990228/tsianina_redfeather_in_france/ "Indian Troupe Busy at Front"], ''Muskogee Times-Democrat'', 26 May 1919, p. 3. Quote: "Miss Redfeather, who is a fullblood Cherokee..."</ref> She trained as a classical singer in [[Denver, Colorado]], sponsored in part by [[Alice Robertson]].<ref>Paige Clark Lush, "The All American Other: Native American Music and Musicians on the Circuit Chautauqua," ''Americana: The Journal of American Popular Culture 1900 to Present'' 7(2)Fall 2008): http://www.americanpopularculture.com/journal/articles/fall_2008/lush.htm</ref>
== Career == At age 26, Redfeather joined American pianist [[Charles Wakefield Cadman]] on tour, giving recitals throughout North America. Cadman, who was white, had studied Native American music from ethnology sources and was lecturing on it, starting in 1908.<ref name="perison"/> He also was creating work drawn from Indian music. In the summer of 1909 he went to Nebraska, where he studied Omaha and Winnebago music on the reservations. He also learned to play some traditional instruments.<ref name="perison"/>
Beginning in 1908, Cadman conducted lecture tours speaking about American Indian music and performed recitals on the subject, including his own songs, and accompanied by Redfeather as singer. They toured both in the United States and later in Europe, so she became known internationally.<ref name="ap"/> As "Princess Tsianina Redfeather", she performed Cadman's compositions wearing traditional costume, with her hair in long braids. She beaded her own garments.<ref>Jared Farmer, ''On Zion's Mount: Mormons, Indians, and the American Landscape'' (Harvard University Press 2009): pp. 344-345.</ref><ref name="perison">[https://www.jstor.org/stable/40375181?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents Harry D. Perison, "The 'Indian' Operas of Charles Wakefield Cadman," ''College Music Symposium'' 22(2)(Fall 1982): 20-48, via JSTOR.]</ref> Cadman's composition "[[From The Land of Sky-Blue Water]]" became Redfeather's signature song.<ref name="upi"/>
She collaborated with Cadman and his librettist [[Nelle Richmond Eberhart]] in creating the opera ''[[Shanewis]]'' (or ''The Robin Woman''). Its contemporary plot was loosely based on Redfeather's semi-autobiographical stories of Native American life, and was set in California and Oklahoma.<ref>Elise Kuhl Kirk, ''American Opera'' (University of Illinois Press 2001): pp. 149-151.</ref> The work debuted at the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in 1918 and was performed also the next season. Highly popular, it toured the United States. Tsianina sang the lead at some performances on tour, making her opera debut in the role in Denver in 1924.<ref name="OperaGlass">{{cite web|title=Shanewis: Performance History|url=http://opera.stanford.edu/Cadman/Shanewis/history.html|publisher=''OperaGlass'', Stanford University|accessdate=August 12, 2012}}</ref> She reprised it in 1926 at the [[Hollywood Bowl]] in Los Angeles.<ref>Beverly Diamond, "Decentering Opera: Early Twentieth-Century Indigenous Production," in Pamela Karantonis and Dylan Robinson, eds., ''Opera Indigene: Re/Presenting First Nations and Indigenous Cultures'' (Ashgate 2011): p. 33.</ref>
During [[World War I]] in 1918, Redfeather was the head of a YMCA-sponsored troupe of Native American entertainers who toured France and Germany, performing for American troops. The title of the show was "The Indian of yesterday and today."<ref name="muskogeeTimes"/> She described the others as "twenty Indian boys".<ref name="muskogeeTimes"/><ref name="autogenerated2001">K. Tsianina Lomawaima, "Tsianina Redfeather Blackstone", in Gretchen M. Bataille and Laurie Lisa, eds., ''Native American Women: A Biographical Dictionary'' (Taylor & Francis 2001): 39-40.</ref> General [[John J. Pershing]] honored her as one of the first women to volunteer to entertain the troops. She was the first woman to cross the Rhine to reach US troops in Germany.<ref name="ap"/>
In 1935, Redfeather retired from singing but was active in working on Indian issues. She was one of the founders of the [[American Indian Education Foundation]] (AIEF).<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1994894/tsianina_blackstone_as_founder_and/ "'Indian Summer' Fashion Tea Will Aid Foundation," ''Valley News'' (October 16, 1956): 9.] via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}</ref>
She also served for 30 years on the Board of Managers for the [[School of American Research]] in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]]. Intended to promote archeological and ethnological research in the United States related to Native Americans, the institute was founded by ethnologist [[Alice Cunningham Fletcher]].<ref name="autogenerated2001"/> Amateur archaeologist [[Edgar Lee Hewett]], who had achieved some status and donated substantial money to the school, was made director. Redfeather recounted that upon meeting Hewett, he told her that he admired the shape of her head and hoped to have it for his museum after she died. "He frightened me," she recalled, "and I had a secret fear of having my skull on display for all to see."<ref>Beatrice Chauvenet, ''Hewett and Friends: A Biography of Santa Fe's Vibrant Era'' (Museum of New Mexico Press 1983): 157-158.</ref>
== Personal life ==
In 1920 Redfeather married David F. Balz of Denver.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1990272/tsianina_redfeather_married_david_balz/ "Colorado Princess Announces Wedding," ''Junction City Daily Union'' (February 26, 1921): 3.] via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}</ref> After they divorced, she remarried. Her second husband was named Blackstone. They also divorced.
Redfeather became a devout [[Christian Scientist]] later in life. She eventually settled in California, where she lived with her niece Wynemah Blaylock (sometimes spelled Blalock) in [[Burbank, California|Burbank]]. They later moved to [[San Diego]].<ref name="ap"/>
In 1981 Redfeather was baptized in the Catholic faith at St. John's Church in San Diego.<ref name="ap">[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1237435/tsianina_redfeather_blackstone_our/ AP, "Famed Indian Singer Dies at Age of 102," ''Santa Cruz Sentinel'' (January 14, 1985): 6.] via [[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}</ref> After Redfeather died in 1985, age 102, a funeral mass for her was held at St. John's.<ref name="ap"/> Her niece said she was descended from "Indian royalty."<ref name="upi">[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1985-01-13/news/8501030298_1_american-indian-princess-san-diego-home UPI, "American Indian Performer Tsianina Redfeather Blackstone," ''Chicago Tribune'' (January 13, 1985)].</ref>

[[Monster Voodoo Machine]] |website = [https://alternativetentacles.com/artists/wesley-willis/ Wesley Willis on Alternative Tentacles] |Movement = [[Outsider art]], [[Landscape art]] }} '''Wesley Lawrence Willis''' (May 31, 1963 – August 21, 2003) was an American [[singer-songwriter]] and [[visual arts|visual artist]]. Diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]] in 1989, Willis began a career as an [[underground music|underground]] [[singer-songwriter]] in the [[outsider music]] tradition, with songs featuring his bizarre, humorous and often obscene lyrics sung over the [[Electronic keyboard#Concepts and definitions|auto accompaniment]] feature on his [[Technics (brand)|Technics]] KN [[electronic keyboard|keyboard]].{{cite web |url=http://wesleywillissjoyrides.com/WesleyWillisBio.htm |title=Wesley Willis's Joy Rides · Wesley Willis Bio |publisher=Wesleywillissjoyrides.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004231454/http://wesleywillissjoyrides.com/WesleyWillisBio.htm |archive-date=2013-10-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.alternativetentacles.com/bandinfo.php?band=wesleywillis |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060419030840/http://www.alternativetentacles.com/bandinfo.php?band=wesleywillis |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-04-19 |title=Bands |publisher=Alternative Tentacles |date= |accessdate=2013-11-21 }}{{cite web |url=http://ymarksthespot.org/2010/07/31/say-rah-discussing-the-daddy-of-rock-n-roll-with-the-directors-of-wesley-williss-joy-rides-2/ |title=Say Rah! Discussing the Daddy of Rock n' Roll with the Directors of "Wesley Willis's Joy Rides" |publisher=Y Marks the Spot |date=2010-07-31 |accessdate=2013-11-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106021117/http://ymarksthespot.org/2010/07/31/say-rah-discussing-the-daddy-of-rock-n-roll-with-the-directors-of-wesley-williss-joy-rides-2/ |archive-date=2014-11-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Willis gained a large [[cult following]] in the 1990s, particularly after the release of his 1995 ''Greatest Hits'' album on the [[Alternative Tentacles]] label. [[Jello Biafra]] compiled the album's track list. In addition to a large body of solo musical work, Willis fronted his own [[punk rock]] band, the [[Wesley Willis Fiasco]], during the 1990s. He was also a visual artist long before he developed an interest in music, and produced hundreds of intricate, unusual, colored ink-pen drawings, most of them of various Chicago streetscapes; he frequently sold these on the street for between $20 and $40. Despite his mainly underground career, Willis has influenced a variety of media: for example, music software company [[Nullsoft]] took their slogan "It really whips the llama's ass!" for [[Winamp]] from Willis's song "Whip The Llama's Ass".DEMO.MP3 15,592 bytes, 32 kbit/s, 22 kHz, recorded in "1997" "Exclusively for Nullsoft" by JJ McKay. Voice only, no music stinger.{{cite web|author=Kushner, David |date=January 13, 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321025028/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5938320/the_worlds_most_dangerous_geek |archivedate=2007-03-21 |title=The World's Most Dangerous Geek|publisher= Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5938320/the_worlds_most_dangerous_geek|accessdate=2010-07-03}} ==Life and career== Willis was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] on May 31, 1963, to Walter{{cite book|last=Knight|first=Michael|title=Blue-Eyed Devil: A Road Odyssey Through Islamic America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EqEXqPXNKmcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Blue-Eyed+Devil:+A+Road+Odyssey+Through+Islamic+America+wesley+willis&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo96SKoK_XAhUKrFQKHQovAeoQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=Wesley%20Willis&f=false|date=March 26, 2009|publisher=Soft Skull Press|isbn=9781593763510|page=10}} and Annie Willis.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2000/11/24/songs-in-his-head/f728dfbe-4f72-41a8-b02f-efb8663c3dec/|title=Songs in His Head|last=Copel|first=Lib|date=November 24, 2000|work=Washington Post|accessdate=7 November 2017}} According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', "Willis grew up in Chicago's [[Public housing|projects]] as one of 10 children of parents who had a violent relationship and separated when he was young; he spent time in several foster homes and was essentially raised by two older brothers, who went with him from home to home."{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Randy |date=August 25, 2003 |title=Wesley Willis, 40; Schizophrenic Found 'Joy' as Rock Performer |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/aug/25/local/me-willis25 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |location=Los Angeles |access-date=July 6, 2015 }} Willis began [[schizophrenia|hearing voices]] during a period of living at his mother's home in the 1980s, when her boyfriend held a gun to his head and robbed him of $100 Willis had saved.{{cite book|last=Chusid|first=Irwin|title=Songs in the Key of Z: The Curious Universe of Outsider Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kT9dnDaFdX8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Songs+in+the+Key+of+Z:+The+Curious+Universe+of+Outsider+Music&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYmIL7oa_XAhVpqlQKHSD2ApgQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=Wesley%20Willis&f=false|year=2000|publisher=Chicago Review Press|isbn=9781569764930|chapter=10}} By the end of the 1980s, he was diagnosed with [[paranoid schizophrenia]]{{cite news|url=http://digitalcommons.conncoll.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1004&context=ccnews_2001_2002|title=El 'N' Gee Hosts Head-Butting Superstar Wesley Willis|last=Cunningham|first=Taylor|date=September 28, 2001|work=The College Voice|accessdate=8 November 2017}} and institutionalized for two months after his diagnosis.{{cite news|title=The Daddy of Rock 'n' Roll|last=Bitton|first=Daniel|date=April 22, 2003|publisher=Mvd Visual}} During childhood, Willis developed an interest in art, and in 1988, he was featured in a Chicago [[public-access television|public access]] documentary feature entitled ''Wesley Willis: Artist of the Streets''.{{cite news|title=Wesley Willis: Artist of the Streets|last=Hart|first=Carl|publisher=Chicago Public Access TV|accessdate=7 November 2017}} In ''Artist of the Streets'', he was shown walking through Chicago's [[Chicago Loop|Loop]] neighborhood, producing his [[fountain pen|ink pen]] drawings outside of the [[Marshall Field and Company Building]], and interacting with people curious about his art. The drawings typically encompass detailed Chicago streetscapes, including buildings, vehicles, trees, and landmarks. Willis was known for his ability to draw from memory a completely different location than the one in which he was sitting. During his lifetime, he frequently gave his drawings away to friends or sold them for small amounts (typically $10 or $20) in Chicago parks. However, after his death, Willis began to receive recognition in the art community for his large body of visual art. In 2008 his artwork was exhibited at the [[Mohamed Khalil Museum]] of Egypt, and he was the subject of a special exhibit entitled ''Drawn By Wesley Willis'' at [[Dominican University (Illinois)|Dominican University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/chicago/articles/its-drawn-by-wesley-willis,520/|title=It's drawn by Wesley Willis|last=Wolinsky|first=David|date=February 21, 2008|work=The A.V. Club Chicago|accessdate=12 March 2012}} {{dead link|date=June 2018}} In 1991, after befriending some musicians from Chicago's alternative rock scene and recording several solo albums, he formed the punk rock band The [[Wesley Willis Fiasco]]. The band developed a popular underground following as well as attention from musicians such as [[Eddie Vedder]], [[Henry Rollins]], [[Mike D.]], [[Jello Biafra]], and the members of [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]];{{cite news|url=http://scholarworks.bgsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=7023&context=bg-news|title=Wesley Willis Fiasco uses music for inner peace|last=Weisbrod|first=Aaron|date=June 26, 1996|work=The BG News|page=6|accessdate=8 November 2017}} and soon caught the attention of [[Rick Rubin]] at [[American Recordings (record label)|American Recordings]], an independent label distributed by [[Warner Bros.|The Warner Group]]. In early 1994, Willis recorded with the [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[industrial music|industrial]]-[[heavy metal music|metal]] band [[Monster Voodoo Machine]] and appeared on their Juno Award-winning debut album ''Suffersystem'' ([[RCA Records]]). In 1995, American Recordings signed Willis as a solo musician; the Wesley Willis Fiasco subsequently broke up in 1996. He went on to record numerous solo albums of [[novelty song|novelty rock]] (two for American Recordings and the remainder for several independent labels or recorded, marketed and released independently by Willis himself), toured frequently, and was profiled on [[MTV]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1477150/wesley-willis-schizophrenic-street-singer-dies/|title=Wesley Willis, Schizophrenic Street Singer, Dies|work=MTV News}} On September 26, 1996, he was a guest on ''[[Howard Stern|The Howard Stern Show]]'' where he played nearly identical songs about [[Baba Booey]] and [[Howard Stern]]. During his many tours and live appearances, Willis became "famous for greeting fans with a headbutt"; this left him with a distinctive permanent bruise on his forehead. In early 2003 the documentary ''[[The Daddy of Rock 'n' Roll]]'' was released, chronicling Willis' daily life and interests. On August 21, 2003, Willis died due to complications from [[chronic myelogenous leukemia]] in [[Skokie, Illinois]]. In 2013, a supporting character named Milan was introduced for the ongoing [[Wonder Woman]] comic. A blind demigod with the power of far-sight and half-brother to Wonder Woman, his physical appearance and mannerisms are based on Wesley Willis.{{cite web|url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/07/wesley-willis-wonder-woma_n_2639862.html|title=Wesley Willis Wonder Woman: Iconic Artist Appears In New DC Comic As Heroine's Half-Brother|accessdate=2 November 2014}} ==Song structure and themes== "Hellride" is the term used by Willis to describe his encounters with "[[demon]]s",{{cite web|url=http://www.monzy.org/wesley/ |title=Wesley Willis |publisher=Monzy.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-21}} which occurred mainly on the [[Chicago Transit Authority|CTA]] bus lines in [[Chicago]]. According to Willis, his demons were trying to ruin his "Harmony Joy Music" or "Joy Rides". He uses the term in many of his songs, such as "I Deserve a Warhellride". The [[Wesley Willis Fiasco]] songs were [[punk rock]] songs with Willis howling his obscene, absurd rants as lyrics. The band recorded three cover songs: [[Thin Lizzy]]'s "Jailbreak",{{cite web |url=http://www.hbdirect.com/album_detail.php?pid=207448 |title=Various Artists: Vagabonds of the Midwestern World: Fighting Songs by Thin Lizzy - A - HBDirect Rock |publisher=Hbdirect.com |date=2003-01-03 |accessdate=2013-11-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508030604/http://www.hbdirect.com/album_detail.php?pid=207448 |archive-date=2014-05-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }} [[Pure Prairie League]]'s "[[Bustin' Out|Amie]]", and [[Duran Duran]]'s "[[Girls on Film]]", the last of which was recorded for a 1997 Duran Duran [[tribute album]]. Another song by the Wesley Willis Fiasco, "The Bar Is Closed", recreates a section of [[Rush (band)|Rush]]'s "Tom Sawyer"; the song "Casper the Homosexual Friendly Ghost" does the same with [[Van Halen]]'s "Jamie's Cryin'". As a solo artist, Willis filled his albums with funny, bizarre, tense, and often obscene statements about crime, fast food, cultural trends, bus routes, violent confrontations with [[superhero]]es, commands for his "demons" to engage in [[bestiality]] (in ''[[The Daddy of Rock 'n' Roll]]'', Willis explained that these songs would "gross out" the demons enough to leave him alone), and praise for his favorite actors, friends, politicians, and [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[rock music|rock]] artists. Songs about rock artists were usually confined to describing a show performed by the band that Willis had attended or opened for, recycling key phrases such as "The crowd roared like a lion," "A lot of people met the band," or "The band got down like a [[Magikist]]". Many songs end with the phrase "Rock over [[London]], rock on, Chicago," followed by a product slogan, such as "[[Wheaties]]. Breakfast of Champions" or "[[Blockbuster LLC|Blockbuster]]. Wow! What a difference." Critic [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Allmusic]] wrote that despite Willis' prolific output his songs were essentially variations on the same simple structure, melody and lyrical themes. He also questioned record company motives for releasing albums by Willis: "It's certainly admirable that Willis has decided to not be tied down by his schizophrenia, but it often seems that his audience is laughing at him, not with him."https://www.allmusic.com/album/feel-the-power-mw0000648886 Erlewine also wrote that listening to a Willis record felt "exploitive". ==Partial discography==
